loan.name: Da

texts.en:
Mrs. Da U. lives in Trapaing Saum Village in Takeo Province. She is 48 years old and the mother of four children. One of her children is an air-conditioner repairer, another attends the local school, and the remaining children stay at home and help on the farm and do housework.
Mrs. Da U. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Long Nin, is a motorbike taxi driver who earns a small income to support the family. Even thought they work hard, they still have trouble providing a good standard of living for their family. Therefore, Mrs. Da U. is requesting a loan to buy a cow to breed.
She is pictured with her husband.

loan.use: to buy a cow to breed

loan.name: Sajida Parveen M. Arshad Group

texts.en:
Sajida Parveen baji is a 33-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this town for the past 14 years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he is a factory worker. She has four kids: two sons and two daughters. None of her children goes to school.

Sajida baji is involved in a milk-selling business with an experience of 9 years. She has got good recognition for her hard work. Sajida baji does this work to improve her familyâ€™s living standard. She means to continue to do this work until she is satisfied with the living standard of her family, e.g. when she is able to send her children to school and renovate her house. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her milk-selling business.

Sajida baji is the group leader for some more women. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell. Mukhtayaran baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (tea and sugar) for her tea stall. Rehana Kosar baji wants a loan to buy an ox to till the land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy another buffalo for her milk-selling business

loan.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mr. Mon D. lives in Tuol Tra Village in Takeo Province. He is 30 years old and the father of four children. Three of the children are enrolled at the local school while the youngest stays at home. He is pictured with his wife, Mrs. Ouk Sary, who sells fish and cultivates rice on her plot of land.
Mr. Mon D. is a fisherman. Although he and his wife work hard, they still cannot provide a good standard of living for their family. Therefore, Mr. Mon D. is requesting a loan to purchase a cow to start a breeding business. He hopes to provide a better life for his family.

loan.use: to purchase a cow to start a breeding business

loan.name: Sakina M. Hanif Khan Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a 43-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 23 years. Her husband's name is M. H. K. and he is a farmer and sells milk as well. She is the mother of seven children: five sons and two daughters. Her first two sons are factory workers. The others don't have work right now.

Sakina baji is involved in a business sewing clothes. Her daughter helps her cut the dresses. She does this work to help her husband to meet their financial expenses. She is applying for a loan to start a grocery shop for her eldest son so that he will be able to manage his own business and earn a good profit.

Sakina baji is the group leader for some more women. Asghari and Jamila baji each want a loan to buy buffaloes for their milk-selling businesses. Saira baji wants a loan to buy wood-cutting tools to cut wood to sell. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy groceries to start a grocery shop

loan.name: Thavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thavy L. lives in Kvav Village in Takeo Province. She is 36 years old and the mother of six children. Four of her children attend the local school and the other two stay at home because they are young. Her husband, Mr. Im Thea, is a motorbike taxi driver. He is pictured with his wife.
Mrs. Thavy L. sells coconuts for a living. Currently, she does not have enough money to buy coconuts to re-sell. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy coconuts and two carts, which will help her transport the coconuts to the market.

loan.use: to buy coconuts and two carts

loan.name: Soren

texts.en:
Mrs. Soren C. lives in Trapaing Pour Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 28 years old and is the mother of a young child. Her husband, Mr. Krouch Nat, is a construction worker.
Mrs. Soren C. sells bamboo for a living. Aside from this business, she is also a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at better price. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy more rice. She hopes to increase income and improve her family's living conditions.

loan.use: to buy more rice to re-sell

loan.name: Kariakoo Group

texts.en:
Mwanaisha H., 40, is divorced and has a 15-year-old son. She also supports her mother and her father. She runs a food market, which she started 6 years ago. She works daily from 6am until 1pm. She realizes a monthly profit of around $292.
This will be Mwanaishaâ€™s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to restock her store, and she repaid the loans successfully. She now hopes for the second loan to restock her grocery again.
Mwanaisha will share this loan with her group, Kariakoo, which has five members who run shops, work as tailors, and sell clothes. The members of the subgroup hold each other accountable for repaying their loans. In the picture, Mwanaisha is shown at the rear, 2nd from the right.

loan.use: To restock a grocery store

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase more fish to re-sell

loan.name: Soeurn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeurn T., 48, makes rice cakes and sells them in her village. She is the leader of a group of three women seeking loans. She is married to Mr. Touch Phanny, 50, who works as a photographer at wedding parties and other special occasions. She has nine children, three of whom are married. Two of her daughters are wedding decorators and help support the family and pay expenses for the four children still in school. To expand her husband's business and improve the service they offer, Soeurn T. is asking for a loan so that her husband can buy photographic supplies.
The group also includes the following two women: Soeurn L., 40, sells cooked foods and raises pigs. She would use the loan to buy ingredients for the dishes she sells. Nop N., 42, carves wood and sells her carvings. She would use the a loan to expand her business. The women in this group live in Battambang Province.

loan.use: To purchase photographic supplies

loan.name: Nan

texts.en:
Mrs. Nan S. lives in Trapaing Kok Village in Takeo Province. She is 27 years old and the mother of three children. One of her children attends the local school while the others stay at home because they are too young.
Mrs. Nan S. is a farmer who cultivates land on a small plot of land. Her husband, Mr. Nop Roeurng (pictured), is a blacksmith who makes knives, ploughs, etc. Since his business is going well, he wants to buy steel to make all kinds of agricultural equipment. Therefore, Mrs. Nan S. is asking for a loan to buy steel for her husband's business.

loan.use: to buy steel for her husband's business

loan.name: Nim

texts.en: Mrs. Nim N. was born in 1973, and she now lives in Trapaing Kok village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. N. Vanny, is a blacksmith who makes all kinds of agricultural equipment. Because this business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Nim N. decided to ask for a loan to buy more steel for her husband's business. She has a child who stays at home because that child is only five years old. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more steel for her husband's agricultural equipment business.

loan.name: Yen's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Yen S. is the group leader of four people who all live in Aleng village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a basket maker who can make a small income to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Heng Mao, is a construction worker. Because his work place is far from home and he usually spends a lot of money on transportation, Mrs. Yen S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a bicycle for her husband to use to go to work. Mrs. Yen S. is 30 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only a year old. Mrs. Yan K. did not come to take her loan, but her husband did, so he is in the photo instead of her.

loan.use: To buy a bicycle for her husband to use to commute to work.

loan.name: Deng's Group

texts.en:
Deng C. is the leader of a group of five members. She is 23 years old, and makes a living selling fish in the local market. She buys the fish from the fishermen or wholesale supplier and then sells it. She currently earns an income of approximately of $2 a day. She has no children and is married to Choum Sarin, who is 28. He has a business of providing water to his neighbors. Deng C. hopes to enlarge both her and her husband's businesses. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish to sell, as well as a pump line, so that her husband can pump more water for sale.
The other four members of the group are: Chou T. is 55 years old and widowed. She sells fish and has applied for a loan as capital for her business. Dom S. is 58 years old and widowed. She also sells fish in the market, and requested a loan to buy more fish to sell for additional income. Sun S. is 57 years old and makes a living catching fish to sell. She seeks a loan to buy more fishing tools like nets. Soan S. is 32 years old and is a fisher. She needs a loan to purchase additional fish tools.
All of the borrowers live in Chong Kneas Commune of Siem Reap Province.

loan.use: To buy more fish for sale and a pump line

loan.name: Thy

texts.en: Mrs. Thy K. is a villager in Takoul village in Kampong Chhnang province. She owns one hectare to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Loem Sin, is a construction worker. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than is necessary to provide better conditions for the family. Also, the family members live in an old house. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Thy K. decided to ask for a loan to combine with her savings to build a new house for the family. Mrs. Thy K. is 35 years old and the mother of five children -- two of whom are construction workers, while another two are attending the local school, and the youngest one is only a year old and too young to work or study.

loan.use: To help build a new house for the family.

loan.name: Mrs. Mas Sen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan (loan group), which consists of 12 people, is located in Svay Bakav village in Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Mas S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. In rice farming, she now faces a small problem because she wants to cultivate in the dry season; unfortunately, she does not have enough rice seeds for cultivation. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice seeds for her rice plantation during the dry season. Mrs. Mas S. is a widow with a child who is a student in the local school.
All the members in this village bank loan have end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKâ€™s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodiaâ€™s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKâ€™s clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva's Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy more rice seeds for her rice plantation during the dry season.

loan.name: Eit

texts.en: Mrs. Eit S. is a villager in Takol village in Kampong Chhnang province. She owns one hectare to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Prak Phan, helps her on the plantation. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little revenue from the rice to support the family. Also, they live in an old house. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Eit S. decided to ask for a loan to use with her savings to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Eit S. is 55 years old and the mother of three children who are all working as construction workers.

loan.use: To help build a new house for her family.

loan.name: Maria Makyao's Group

texts.en:
Maria M., age 45, is married with four children ages 22, 20, 12 and 10. She has a tailoring business, which she started in 1994 and she works from 1pm until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $150.

This will be Mariaâ€™s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to open another business, a genge (food stand) where she sells tomatoes, vegetables, rice, sugar, beans and wheat flour. She will use her fifth loan to increase stock on the genge and buy more materials.

Maria will share this loan with her loan group, Upendo Mloganzila, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Maria is sitting in the middle of the front row.

loan.use: To buy more materials and increase stock for a food stand.

loan.name: Mrs. Arn Cheng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank (loan group), which consists of nine people, is located in Phum Thmey village in Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Arn C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. In vegetable farming, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy bean seeds to grow on the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy them. Mrs. Arn C. is a 59-year-old widow with two children who both help her on the plantation. Mrs. Bung Y. did not come to take her loan, but her husband did, so he takes her place in the photo.

All the members in this village bank have end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKâ€™s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodiaâ€™s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKâ€™s clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva's Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy bean seeds to grow on the field.

loan.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S. is a 37 year old resident of Pursat Province. She sells groceries and cakes for children from her house. She started her business in 2000, and currently earns a net profit of $2 each day. She is married with four children, all of whom are single and attend school.
Her husband, Mr. So Rin, 38, is a local cultivator. He grows rice and vegetable crops. Crops are the main way for him to earn a living. He now works hard on growing his crops and hopes to enlarge his business, thus after discussion with his wife, they decided to request a loan to buy an extra plot of farmland for growing crops. (Long S.'s husband is pictured, because she was not available that day.)

loan.use: To buy extra a plot of farmland for growing crops.

loan.name: Chang Lim

texts.en: Mrs. Chang Lim T. is a villager in Trapaing Ampil village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for the household. Her husband, Mr. Nem Mao, owns a small shop from which he sells construction supplies. In this business, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy steel to re-sell. Thus his wife, Mrs. Chang Lim T., decided to ask for a loan to buy it for her husband. Mrs. Chang Lim T. is 34 years old and the mother of two children who are both attending the local school. Her husband is presented next to her in the photo.

loan.use: To buy steel for her husband's metal shop.

loan.name: Vannath

texts.en: Mrs. Vannath N. was born in 1945, and she now lives in Khvet Thom village in Kampong Cham province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for the family. Her husband, Mr. Ork Nuon, is a bicycle repairer. Because this business is going well, he wants to expand it. So his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more bicycle supplies for her husband's business. Mrs. Vannath N. is married without any children. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more supplies for her husband's bicycle repair business.

loan.name: Rosila

texts.en:
Rosila J. is a member in good standing of Mahayahay Center in Usocan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old and married to Danny. Rosila and her husband only finished high school. Hard work is what they have to do to live a good life, Rosila said.
Armed with the desire to have their own business, they began a fishing business. The couple need a lantern for fishing, which is will provide light in the dark with the use of a battery. They applied for a loan to purchase the lantern. Luckily, Paglaum MPC released the said amount. A portion of the amount will be used to purchase a blinker, which is another fishing accessory, used to attract a good catch of squid. Just like any other business, fishing has its many challenges. When fishing is banned for a period of time, her husband works in construction as a sideline. It's a matter of "diskarte" (strategies) on how to earn a living. In the future, Rosila and Danny want to repair their house from their earnings.

loan.use: To purchase a lantern for fishing.

loan.name: Thea

texts.en:
Mr. Thea M. is a villager in Trapaing Touk village in Kampong Cham province. He is a blacksmith. He now faces a problem because he does not have enough supplies for his own business. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Thea M. decided to ask for a loan to buy all kinds of blacksmith supplies.

His wife, Mrs. Srey Phalla, is a housewife. Mr. Thea M. is 31 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only three years old. His wife is presented on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy all kinds of blacksmith supplies.

loan.name: Maryam Dani El Group

texts.en:
Maryam baji is a 56-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She completed her education up to 8th standard but couldnâ€™t study further because of lack of financial resources from her parents. Her husband's name is D. E. and he has an animal-selling business. He buys animals from animal markets and sells specifically goats to butcher shops. He has 20 years' experience in this business.

Maryam baji has two sons. Her elder son has a vegetable-selling business, and her younger son has a brick-selling business. Maryam baji keeps herself busy making embroidered dresses and doing knitting. She knits table covers and bed sheets and sells them in the market at a profit. She invests her income in a committee. She intends to marry off her elder son when she collects her committee amount. She is a regular member of Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). She has successfully repaid five loans and now she is requesting her 6th loan to buy goats to expand her husband's animal-selling business.

Maryam baji is the group leader for some more women. Sakina baji and another lady called Sakina baji each want a loan to buy buffaloes for their milk-selling businesses. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rehana baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart to carry loads.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy animals to re-sell

loan.name: Samreth

texts.en: Mr. Samreth K. was born in 1968, and he now lives in Trapaing Touk village in Kampong Cham province. He is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and then re-sell later at a better price. Because this business is going well, he wants to expand it. So he decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell. His wife, Mrs. Sem Limsaeang, helps him in the current business. Mr. Samreth K. has two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is only three years old and too young to work or study. His wife is shown on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more rice to re-sell.

loan.name: Put

texts.en:
Put H. is 28 years old and sells Khmer silk clothes by transporting them to customers' homes. She buys them from the manufacturer and then resells them for a profit. She has been in this business since 2003, and currently earns around $10 per day. Her husband, Mr. Pheng Kreal, is 41 years old and works cooking for wedding parties. The couple has two children, both of whom are teenagers. They both work hard with the business to support the family's living expenses.
So far, her business is doing well and she needs to expand it to make more profits. Therefore, Put H. would like to request a loan to purchase more silk clothes for resale. The loan will help to improve her business.

loan.use: To purchase more silk clothes for resale.

loan.name: Alveena Yunas Group

texts.en:
Alveena baji is a 44-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the past 15 years. She is an uneducated lady. Her husband's name is Y. and he is a driver, driving a horse cart which he uses to bring people from one place to another, charging a fare.

Alveena baji is the mother of four kids: one son and three daughters. Her son is a daily wage laborer. Her daughters stay at home and do household work and take care of the family. Alveena baji belongs to the milk-selling profession. She has a buffalo at her house and from her, she gets milk which she sells to milk shops. She has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo for her milk-selling business.

Alveena baji is the group leader for some more women. Shakeela baji and Noreen baji each want a loan to buy bricks to re-sell. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy land on contract to grow vegetables. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy chairs and tools for her family's barbershop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy another buffalo for her milk-selling business

loan.name: Meur

texts.en: Mrs. Meur R. is a villager in Svay Prey village in Kampong Cham province. She is a pig breeder. Because this business is going well, she wants to expand it; so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food for her breeding business. Her husband, Mr. Run Len, is a farmer who owns a small plot of land to cultivate rice. This couple lives without any children, but they try to work hard in order to support themselves. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more piglets and pig food for her breeding business

loan.name: Bilquis Manzoor Masih Group

texts.en:
Bilquis baji is a 48-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 18 years. Her husband's name is M. M. and he is a farmer. She has no children. She spends most of her time sewing clothes and making embroidered clothes. This activity gives her rewards in the form of money. She invests a part of her income in her husbandâ€™s land and a part to furnish her house. She is applying for a loan to buy an ox to till the land belonging to her husband.

Bilquis baji is the group leader for a few more women. Safia, Seema and Irshad baji each want a loan to buy buffaloes for their milk-selling business. Another lady called Irshad baji wants a loan to buy bricks to re-sell. Jabeen baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (taps, pipes) for her sanitary supply business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy an ox to till their land

loan.name: Srorn

texts.en: Mrs. Srorn C. was born in 1973, and she now lives in Kampan Village in Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Hit Khin, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Although they try to work hard on their plantation, they still can earn little rice revenue to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Srorn C. decided to ask for a loan to buy 125 ducks to start duck breeding business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her ducks. Mrs. Srorn C. has six children -- one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school and the youngest one is only one year old and too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy 125 ducks to start duck breeding business.

loan.name: Rehana Sarfraz Masih Group

texts.en:
Rehana baji is a 34-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the past 17 years. Her husband's name is S. M. and he is a farmer. She is the mother of two sons. Both are factory workers. Rehana baji performs her duties as a mother and as a wife along with as a woman. She knits clothes to help her husband. She knits table cloths and bed sheets and goes to the market to sell them. She is applying for a loan to buy an ox to till the land of her husband.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Saira baji and Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy material (hard paper) for their shoebox-making business. Joshphein baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy an ox to till the land

loan.name: Yeur

texts.en: Mr. Yeur Y. is a villager in Svay Prey village in Kampong Cham province. He is a pig breeder. Because this business is going well, he wants to expand it; so he decided to ask for a loan to buy three more pigs for breeding. He would use the rest of the loan to buy pig food to feed his pigs. His wife, Mrs. Mon Tha, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Mr. Yeur Y. is 27 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only three years old. His wife is shown on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy three more pigs and pig food for his pig breeding business.

loan.name: Rasheeda Nadeem Group

texts.en:
Rasheeda baji is a 33-year-old married lady and resides in a place called Kot Radha Kishan which is 24 km from the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the past 10 years. Her husband's name is N. and he has a ready-made garment sales business. He runs a shop in the main bazaar of Kot Radha Kishan and sells his garment collection. His collection attracts a pack of people and forces them to buy it.

Rasheeda baji has no children. She helps her husband by buying some of the garments in the community. She has successfully repaid two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institution of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more garments to re-sell.

She is the group leader for a few more women from her locality. Zareena baji and Mussarat baji each want a loan to buy beams for their shuttering business. Rukhsana baji and Ghulam Fatima baji want a loan to buy buffaloes for their milk-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy garments to re-sell

loan.name: Srey Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey Mao H. was born in 1982, and she now lives in Por Steang village in Kampong Cham. She is a duck breeder. Her ducks are getting bigger and bigger, and she does not have enough money to buy duck food to feed them. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Srey Mao H. decided to ask for a loan buy duck food.

Her husband, Mr. Chaom Cheng Ly, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Srey Mao H. has three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study because they are only one and four years old. Her husband is presented next to her in the photo.

loan.use: To buy duck food for her duck breeding business.

loan.name: Bo

texts.en: Mrs. Bo S. is a widowed porridge seller who lives in Kandal Province. She sells a variety of food including porridge and noodle soups from her house in the village. She has three children, all of whom are single; one works as a construction worker, one works selling fishes, and another one is in school. S. also cares for her old mother. To expand the business and improve income, S. would like to request a loan to purchase ingredients to make porridge and noodle soup selling. Any remaining amount will be used to decorate her business stall.

loan.use: to purchase ingredients to make porridge and noodle soup

loan.name: Tiem

texts.en:
Mrs. Tiem S. is a duck breeder who lives in Por Steang village in Kampong Cham province. Because her ducks have grown very fast, she does not have enough money to buy food to feed them; so she decided to ask for a loan to buy duck food.

Her husband, Mr. Phin Phan, is a farmer who can gather a little rice revenue, which cannot support the family well. Mrs. Tiem S. is 45 years old and the mother of five children -- one of whom is a chicken seller, while another three are attending the local school, and the youngest one is only two years old and too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy duck food for her duck breeding business.

loan.name: Yann

texts.en: Yann S. lives in Kandal Province and is widowed. She is 76 years old and makes a living by renting a house. She has run her business for a long time and is earning an income of $250 per month. She is a mother of four children; two are single and another two are married. To help a little more with the family's needs, one daughter is working as a motorcycle parking keeper. S. proposes to make a new investment, but she is lacking the money to make that possible. Thus she would like to apply for a loan to purchase rice to store and sale. The loan will help her increase her income more to sustain her family's living expenses adequately.

loan.use: To purchase rice to store and sale

loan.name: Khann

texts.en: Mrs. Khann K. is a 59-year-old widow with two children one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the remaining one is immigrant who works in Malaysia. Mrs. Khann K. is a villager in Taing Srey village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectar field where she cultivates rice for a living. She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough rice seeds to cultivate rice in the dry season. Thus, Mrs K. has decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy more rice seeds for this purpose. In addition, she would use the rest of the loan to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field and purchase fertilizers to support the field.

loan.use: To buy more rice seeds, to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field, and to purchase fertilizers.

loan.name: Sophat

texts.en: Mrs. Sophat N. was born in 1971 and she now lives in Trapaing Ampil village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband have three children two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is on the age of a year. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Vann Sophat, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar or wine. In this business, he now faces a problem because he does not have enough bamboo to tie to the palm tree to climb up to gather juice. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Sophat N. decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy more bamboo for her husband's business. Her husband appears on the left of photo.

loan.use: To buy more bamboo for her husband's business.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To hire laborers to work on the field.

loan.name: Man

texts.en: Mrs. Man O., 55, grows crops for sale. She grows morning glory vegetable and sells in the market, and has been growing since 1995. She is married to Mr. Chuch Ie with five children, four of whom are married and one daughter is single, working in a garment factory. With much experience growing morning glory, her business is going well so far and can support her family sufficiently. Because of insufficient farmland to grow the crop for sale, O. needs to rent the farmland from her neighbors by paying rent annually. Hence, she now would like to request a loan to pay for renting farmland, purchase seeds, and to build a gate to protect her crops.

loan.use: a loan to pay for renting farmland, purchase seeds, and to build a gate to protect her crops

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To hire a plot of land to cultivate potatoes.

loan.name: Oeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Oeurn O. is a villager in Chi Paing village in Kampong Cham province. She is 44 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. Mrs. Oeurn O. is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. In her vegetable farming, she grows potatoes on 4-hectar field which it is too big for her to work so she has decided to ask for a loan of to hire laborers to work on the field. Her husband, Mr. Preap Sophal, helps her in the plantation.

loan.use: To hire laborers to work on the field.

loan.name: Uk

texts.en: Uk S. is 51 years old and lives in Kandal Province. She sells dried fish, as well as roasted fish, at the market. She has been in this business for more than ten years, and currently earns $5 a day to support her family's living expenses. She has ten children, six of whom are single and four are married. Two of her children are employed; one is a grocery seller and another one works for the Country of Korea. Her husband is 59 years old and he works with her in her business. To expand her business, S. is asking for a loan to buy additional dried fish to store and then resell.

loan.use: To buy additional dried fish to store.

loan.name: Pheoun

texts.en: Mr. Pheoun P. was born in 1954 and he now lives in Chrok Rumdeng village in Kampong Cham province. He is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and then to re-sell later at a better price. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it so he decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy more rice to keep in stock. His wife, Mrs. Hoeng Sara, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for the family. Mr. Pheoun P. has two children who are attending the local school. His wife and a child appear with him in the picture.

loan.use: To buy more rice to keep in stock.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To hire laborers to work on that field.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To hire laborers to work in her field.

loan.name: Hat

texts.en:
Hat S. is 35 years old and works raising pigs that she then sells, while her husband makes alcohol to sell. She has been raising pigs since 2002, and normally she can sell them for slaughter in about three or four months. Her husband, Mr. Khim Mab, 44, makes alcohol at their house and sells it to regular customers.
She has three children, all of whom are teenagers and attending school. To increase her income, Hat S. would like to request a loan to purchase more piglets to raise, and rice to resell for a profit. The loan will help to improve her living conditions.

loan.use: To purchase more piglets to raise, and rice for resale.

loan.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov K. is a villager in Chi Paing village in Kampong Cham province. She is 30 years old and the mother of two children who are all attending the local school. She owns a small grocery store in the local market. Since this business is going well, Mrs Pov K. wants to expand and so she decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy grocery goods for her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Ry Khim, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates both rice and vegetables. Her husband is shown on the right in the picture.

loan.use: Tto buy grocery goods for her inventory.

loan.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is divorced with two children. She sells various decorations at the market in Ordzhonikidze city. Her monthly gross income is 26,000 UAH, and her profit is about 3,000 UAH (1 UAH =~0.124 USD).
Nataliya has been in this business for 15 years. She enjoys selling decoration articles. She treats her clients well and always offers them a large variety of products. She has many repeat clients, which makes her business very sustainable.
Nataliya would like to receive a loan to increase her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales during the holiday season and make more money for her family. Nataliya's business goal is to open her own little store.

loan.use: To increase inventory

loan.name: Yuriy

texts.en:
Yuriy is married with two children. He sells bread and other bakery products at a small kiosk in Ordzhonikidze. His income is 3,000 UAH (1 UAH =~0.124USD) per month.
Yuriy has been in this business for 1 year only. He decided to start this particular business because bread and bakery products are always in demand. Yuriyâ€™s business is successful because he tries to offer his clients a large variety of fresh products. Yuriy's business goal is to open a small food store.
Yuriy would like to get a loan to purchase more products for the holiday season. He hopes to increase sales and better provide for his family.

loan.use: To buy more bakery products

loan.name: Oin

texts.en: Mrs. Oin M. is a farmer in Traping Ampil village in Kampong Cham province. Mrs. Oin M. is 55 years old and the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Chhoem Kroeun, is a construction worker who can only make a small income to support the family. Although they try to work hard, they still cannot support the family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Oin M. decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy a cow to start a cattle breeding business. Her husband appears next to her in the picture.

loan.use: To buy a cow to start a cattle breeding business.

loan.name: Bun Chhean

texts.en: Mr. Bun Chhean C. is a villager in Samraong Village in Takeo Province. He is 29 years old and the father of two children who are too young to work or study. He sells Prohok which is made from a small fish and is used with Khmer soup. He is also a tobacco seller. Since these businesses are going well, Mr. Bun Chhean C. wants to expand them. In order to meet customer demand, he decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy more Prohok and tobacco to re-sell His wife, Mrs. Man Srey Oun, is a farmer who has a plot of land where she cultivates rice for a living. She appears on the right in the photo.

loan.use: To buy more Prohok and tobacco to re-sell in order to meet customer demand.

loan.name: Thou

texts.en: Mr. Thou C. is a farmer in Samraong Village in Takeo Province. He is 34 years old and the father of two children who are attending the local school. His wife, Mrs. Khuon Sarim, is a Khmer cake seller in the local village. Although they work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Thou C. decided to ask for a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike. He will become a motorbike taxi driver. With this new loan, he hopes to increase his income and improve the family's living conditions . His wife is shown on the left in the photo.

loan.use: To buy a motorbike to enable him to be a motorbike taxi driver.

loan.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S. is a 68 year old resident of Kandal Province, where she owns and runs a small store selling various kinds of fruit. She currently earns an income of approximately of $5 a day, and has been in business since 2001. She is married with three children, all of whom are single and attend school. Her husband, 59, sells children's toys by bicycle. He normally sells at wedding parties and other ceremonies that are attended by many kids. To increase their income, S. would like to request a loan to purchase more fruit to sell and use the remainder for her husband's business. Her husband is shown in the photograph because she was not available.

loan.use: To purchase more fruit.

loan.name: Abdurabi

texts.ru: ÐÐ±Ð´ÑƒÑ€Ð°Ð±Ð¸ Ð¼ÑƒÐ¶Ñ‡Ð¸Ð½Ð° Ð² Ð²Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°ÑÑ‚Ðµ 37 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ ,Ð¾Ñ‚ÐµÑ† Ð¿ÑÑ‚ÐµÑ€Ñ‹Ñ… Ð´Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÐº, Ð¶ÐµÐ½Ð° Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑ‚ ÑƒÑ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½Ð¸Ñ†ÐµÐ¹ Ð² ÑˆÐºÐ¾Ð»Ðµ.Ð¡Ð°Ð¼ ÐÐ°Ð±Ð¸ÐµÐ² Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² ÐÐ³Ñ€Ð¾Ð¸Ð½Ð²ÐµÑÑ‚Ð±Ð°Ð½ÐºÐµ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ÐšÐ¾ÑÑ‚Ð°ÐºÐ¾Ð·Ð°. texts.en:
Abdurabi N. is a 37 year old man. He is a father to 5 daughters and his wife works as a school teacher. Abdurabi works in the Agroinvestbank in Kostakoz city. His two older daughters are college students. This is why Abdurabi has a side business selling livestock. While livestock is cheap at the markets he would like to take out a loan to purchase two cows. He expresses gratitude to all the investors.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase two cows

loan.name: Evelina

texts.es:
La Sra. Evelina cuenta con 31 aÃ±os de edad, esta casada con el Sr. Osmar Pastor LÃ³pez Paredes de 29 aÃ±os de edad, la misma tiene 1 hija de 4 aÃ±os.
El negocio lo tienen desde el aÃ±o 2.006, los primeros tiempo comenzaron a vender tipo vendedor ambulante llevando mercaderÃ­as especificas y salÃ­a en moto acompaÃ±ado de su marido, viajaban por los distritos aledaÃ±os del Guiara.
La cliente tiene experiencia en el rubro aproximadamente 5 aÃ±os, cuando comenzÃ³ a trabajar como vendedora de una casa comercial en ese entonces dedicada al rubro de electrodomÃ©sticos, durante 3 aÃ±os y fue donde le conociÃ³ al seÃ±or Osmar quien trabajaba en es entonces para otra casa comercial del mismo rubro. Hoy en dÃ­a poseen su negocio propio lo cual le esta yendo muy bien. Ahora tiene un local con muchos productos ademÃ¡s tiene 2 vendedores lo cual salen a hacer las ventas por la campaÃ±a con ellos comenzaron. La cliente solicito el prÃ©stamo para completar su capital para realizar compra de algunas mercaderÃ­as que le faltan, especialmente calzados para caballeros el cual tiene mucha demanda de parte de sus clientes, tambiÃ©n dijo que harÃ­a algunas mejoras en su local especÃ­ficamente modernizar con puerta de vidrio, ya que las mercaderÃ­as son muy azotadas por el polvo y el sol.
texts.en:
Evelina is 31 years old, married to Osmar Pastor LÃ³pez Paredes, age 29, and has a 4-year old daughter. They have owned a business since 2006. Initially, they were street vendors selling a limited variety of merchandise and would go out on her husband's motorcycle to districts surrounding Guiara. This client has 5 years' experience from the time she began working as a salesperson in a home appliances business, where she worked for 3 years and where she met Osmar, who was working in the same line of business for a different company. Today, they own their own business which is doing well. They now have a store where they offer a varitey of products as well as having 2 employees who go out to make sales in the countryside, as they used to when they started their business. The client is requesting the loan to bolster her working capital in order to buy merchandise which they do not have in stock, specifically footwear for men, for which there is a high demand. She also told us that she will make some improvements to the store, particularly to modernize it with a glass door, as the merchandise needs protection from the dust and the sun.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy men's footwear and a glass door for the store.

loan.name: Damaschin

texts.en: Damaschin S. lives in Opaci village in the district of Causeni. Since July 2005, he has worked under contract with â€œDimitradze Djumber Bilaloviciâ€œ in Moscow, Russia, as a driver. He has not previously taken out a loan with Microinvest. Damaschin always had a dream, and his dream is to procure a BMW car, but this car is not cheap. The price of a car is $9000, and he needs a loan because he does not have enough money. He hopes that this loan from Microinvest will make his dream a reality and the car will belong to him, and hopefully his future will get better.

loan.use: To buy a car

loan.name: Qatrawi

texts.en: Quatrawi E. lives in ÅžtefÄƒneÅŸti village, in the district of Stefan Voda. Since February 2008, she has been active in the village ÅžtefÄƒneÅŸti Hall, and is currently the board secretary. She previously worked as a secretary at the City of Stefan-Voda district. She has requested a loan to buy a portable computer, which is very necessary for both her work and her free time. This portable computer will be very helpful in the future.

loan.use: To buy a portable computer

loan.name: Paula Hirma

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Paula es socia del Banco Comunal â€œVÃ­tor Echaveâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Es conviviente y madre de 3 hijos menores de edad a los que mantiene econÃ³micamente. Con el primer prÃ©stamo que recibiÃ³ de S/.500, comprÃ³ artÃ­culos usados para venderlos en su puesto de trabajo. Tiene casi 3 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/.500, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ mÃ¡s artÃ­culos usados para venderlos en su puesto y asÃ­ aumentar sus ganancias. Paula desea seguir trabajando para que sus hijos continÃºen sus estudios y lleguen a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Paula is a member of the 'Vitor Echave' Community Bank in the district, province and department of Puno. She lives with her partner and is the mother of 3 young children. With her first loan of S/. 500 she bought used goods to sell in her stall. She has worked with the community bank for almost 3 years. With this loan of S/. 500 to be repaid in 4 instalments she will buy more used goods to sell in her stall and in this way increase her earnings. Paula hopes to continue working so her children can continue with their studies and pursue professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase used goods

loan.name: Agustina

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Agustina es socia del Banco Comunal â€œDulce Amanecerâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento D. Puno. Tiene 61 aÃ±os D. edad, es casada, tiene 2 hijos. Con su primer prÃ©stamo D. S/. 300 comprÃ³ lana para realizar sus tejidos y venderlos en su puesto D. artesanÃ­as. Nos cuenta que tiene un segundo puesto D. ventas el cual estÃ¡ alquilado y que recibe en pago mensual D. ese alquiler. Tiene casi 8 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal. Con este prÃ©stamo D. S/.3,000, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ mÃ¡s lana e insumos para confeccionar artesanÃ­as y venderlas en su puesto. Agustina desea continuar trabajando para apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Agustina is a member of the 'Dulce Amanecer' Community Bank in the district, province and department of Puno. She is 61 years old, married and the mother of two children. With her first loan of S/. 300 she bought wool for her weavings, which she sells in her handicraft stall. She tells us that she has a second stall which she rents out for a monthly payment. She has worked with the community bank for almost 8 years. With this loan of S/. 3,000 to be repaid in 4 instalments she will buy more wool and craft supplies in order to make handicrafts and sell them in her stall. Agustina hopes to continue working in order to support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase wool and craft supplies to make handicrafts

loan.name: Hayde

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Aide es socia del Banco Comunal â€œFlores la Pampillaâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 22 aÃ±os de edad, es conviviente y madre de 1 hijo. Con su primer prÃ©stamo de S/. 300 comprÃ³ productos para venderlos en su quiosco. Nos cuenta que estudiÃ³ computaciÃ³n pero no ejerce su carrera por estar al cuidado de su bebe. Tiene casi 6 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,200, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ productos para vender en su quiosco y tambiÃ©n juguetes. Agustina desea continuar trabajando para llegar a ser propietaria de una casa.
texts.en:
Hayde is a member of the 'Flores la Pampilla' Community Bank in the district, province and department of Puno. She is 22 years old, lives with her partner and is the mother of one child. With her first loan of S/. 300 she bought merchandise to sell in her kiosk. She tells us that she studied computing but has not pursued this career as she has to look after her baby. She has worked with the community bank for almost six years. With this loan of S/. 1,200 to be repaid in 4 instalments she will buy merchandise including toys to sell in her kiosk. Hayde hopes to continue working so that one day she can own her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase merchandise

loan.name: Andrea

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Andrea es socia del Banco Comunal â€œDante Navaâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 33 aÃ±os de edad, es soltera y madre de 2 hijos. Con su primer prÃ©stamo de S/. 500 comprÃ³ combustible para venderlo en su local. Tiene casi un aÃ±o trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que su negocio funciona en un local alquilado. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 2,500, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ mayor cantidad de combustible para aumentar sus ganancias. Agustina desea continuar trabajando para tener un local propio.
texts.en:
Andrea is a member of the 'Dante Nava' Community Bank in the district, province and department of Puno. She is 33 years old, single and the mother of 2 children. With her first loan of S/. 500 she bought fuel to sell in her shop. She has worked with the community bank for almost one year, and she tells us that she runs her business from rented premises. With this loan of S/. 2,500 to be repaid in 4 instalments she will buy a greater quantity of fuel in order to increase her earnings. Andrea wishes to continue working so that one day she can own her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase fuel

loan.name: Aureliana

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Aureliana es socia del Banco Comunal â€œDante Navaâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 38 aÃ±os de edad, es soltera y madre de 3 hijos. Con su primer prÃ©stamo de S/. 500 comprÃ³ aceite lubricante para auto para venderlo en su local. Tiene casi un aÃ±o trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que tiene una tienda de filtros para auto. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/.1,500, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ filtros y aceite lubricante para auto. Agustina desea continuar trabajando para llegar a ser propietaria de un grifo y un local propio donde vender sus aceites y filtros.
texts.en:
Aureliana is a member of the 'Dante Nava' Community Bank, in the province, district and department of Puno. She is 38 years old, single and the mother of three children. With her first loan of S/. 500 she bought motor oil to sell in her shop. She has worked with the community bank for almost one year and she tells us that she has a shop selling car oil filters. With this loan of S/. 1,500 to be repaid in 4 instalments she will buy filters and motor oil. Aureliana wishes to continue working to become the proprietor of her own petrol station and shop where she can sell motor oil and filters.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase car oil filters and motor oil

loan.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Dar es salaam, Tanzania! This is 43 year old Matilda A. N.. She is a married mother of three children who are between the ages of 6 and 18. She also supports two dependents who attend school near her house. Matilda is a Tanzanian entrepreneur who has been running a poultry business since 2007. In Tanzania it is called a â€œKukuâ€ business, as kuku means chicken in Swahili. Kuku is a favorite among Tanzanians and they make finger-licking good fried chicken here!
Her business is simple, however tedious. She buys chicks, tends to them for five weeks, and then sells them in the market. But as you can see from her photo, tending to chickens is back breaking work!
Her business is doing well and she is able to make an average monthly profit of about US$100. Matilda is requesting a loan in order to buy additional chicks and feed. She thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional chicks and feed

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Invest in her transportation company by purchasing more cars

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Buy skirts and blankets

loan.name: ConcepciÃ³n

texts.es: La seÃ±ora ConcepciÃ³n es socia del Banco Comunal â€œDante Navaâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 31 aÃ±os de edad, es soltera y madre de 3 hijos. Con su primer prÃ©stamo de S/. 300 comprÃ³ lana para confeccionar prendas de vestir. Tiene casi 4 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que con el negocio de los combustibles, al que ahora se dedica, ha aumentado su capital y sus ganancias. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,000, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ combustibles y artÃ­culos de ferreterÃ­a para venderlos en su puesto. Agustina desea continuar trabajando para construir su casa propia y tener un local donde vender sus productos.
texts.en:
Concepcion is an associate of the Communal Bank "Dante Nava," of the district, province and state of Puno. She is 31 years old, single and a mother of three. With her first loan of 300 soles, she bought wool to make clothing. She has been working with the community bank for almost 4 years and tells us that with her current business of selling fuel, she has increased her earnings. With this loan of 1,000 soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy fuel and pieces of iron to sell at her shop. She would like to keep working to build her own home and to have a place to sell her products.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy fuel and hardware

loan.name: Marina

texts.es: Marina se dedica a la venta de equipos pequeÃ±os audio visuales como ser MP3, MP4 y otros. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona Alto la Florida de la de la ciudad de La Paz. Vive en alquiler ya que no cuenta con una vivienda propia. El crÃ©dito serÃ¡ destinado para la compra de mercaderÃ­a (MP3, MP4,FLASH MEMORY Y OTROS) Es una persona luchadora ya que es madre soltera y su pequeÃ±a hija esta en el nivel inicial de Zinder (pre-school).
texts.en:
Marina sells small audio visual equipment such as MP3 and MP4 players. Her home is located in the Alto la Florida zone of the city of La Paz. She lives in a rental home because she does not have her own home. The loan will be used to buy merchandise for her to sell (MP3, MP4, Flash Memory, etc.) She is a person who is a fighter--she is a single mother to her small daughter who is starting pre-school.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy MP3, MP4, flash memory and other electronics to sell

loan.name: Hasadia

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and SELFINA! This is 47 year old Hasadia J S.. She is married woman with five children between the ages of 14 and 26. She has owned a vitenge and tailoring business since 2007.
Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. Women use these colorful and boldly printed fabrics to make traditional Tanzania outfits which usually consist of long fitted skirts and conservative boat necked tops. As such, Hasadia is a smart entrepreneur and does not simply sell vitenge, but also offers her services as a seamstress. Thus, customers can select the cloth and the style of outfit they would like as well as have their measurements taken. Itâ€™s really a one stop shop for women!
Currently her business is able to generate a monthly profit of about USD200 and she is requestring a loan in order to purchase additional vitenge. In future she hopes to further increase the quantity and range of the stock. She thanks you for your support in advance!
ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase additional vitenge (printed fabric).

The loan will be used to buy merchandise (perfumes, creams, shampoo, etc.) This is the fourth time that Rosa has applied for an Impro loan. Her history qualifies her as a premier customer because she has a good record of repaying past loans.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Valeriana

Valeriana makes a living buying and selling "aji" (a kind of chili), "chunos" (sun-dried potatoes) and "mote" (boiled maize). Her husband is a cab driver. She lives in the Irpavi II neighborhood of La Paz and has three school-aged children. She needs the loan to buy merchandise (aji, chuno and mote). This is her sixth loan from Impro. Her history qualifies her as a premier customer because she has a good record of repaying past loans.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Damiana

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Damiana es socia del Banco Comunal â€œMujeres de Villa del Lago IIâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 42 aÃ±os de edad, es casada y madre de 7 hijos. Con el primer prÃ©stamo de S/ 300 comprÃ³ insumos para su negocio de venta de comidas preparadas. Tiene casi 3 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que ha conseguido realizar la mayor parte de sus proyectos con los prÃ©stamos del banco comunal debido a que aumentÃ³ sus ganancias. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 3,000, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ mayor cantidad de insumos para aumentar la venta de comidas preparadas. Francisca desea continuar trabajando para apoyar a sus hijos para que lleguen a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Damiana is a member of the Mujeres de Villa del Lago II ["Women of Villa del Lago II"] community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Puno. She is 42-years old, married and the mother of 7 children. With her first loan of S/.300 [300 Peruvian soles], she bought supplies for her food business. She has worked with the bank for almost 3 years and she tells us that she has managed to carry out most of her plans with the loans and, consequently, increased her earnings. With this S/.3,000 loan, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy bigger quantities of supplies so that she can increase her food sales. Damiana hopes to continue working so that she can support her children and see them take up professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loan.name: Aurelia

texts.es: Aurelia es casada, su esposo es mecÃ¡nico de maquinaria pesada en una compaÃ±Ã­a que fabrica plataformas marinas. Ellos son padres de 3 hijos adolescentes. Ella iniciÃ³ el negocio porquÃ© deseaba ganar dinero extra, ya que aunque tiene trabajo como enfermera, los ingresos familiares no eran suficientes para costear los gastos de la casa y los estudios de sus hijas. EmpezÃ³ vendiendo productos cosmÃ©ticos en su trabajo y con sus vecinas y como le empezÃ³ a ir bien decidiÃ³ tambiÃ©n vender productos de plÃ¡stico para el hogar, ya que son muy solicitados por las amas de casa. Poco a poco ha ido progresando en su negocio por lo que hace 6 meses tambiÃ©n se esta dedicando a la venta de ropa ya que se dio cuenta que tambiÃ©n era un buen negocio y gracias a Dios ha tenido tambiÃ©n buena aceptaciÃ³n entre mis clientes. Ella necesita un prÃ©stamo por MXN $5000 que pagara en 10 catorcenas para comprar mercancÃ­a que le permitirÃ¡ surtir pedidos de los productos de plÃ¡stico para el hogar que le han hecho sus clientes ademÃ¡s de comprar ropa para frÃ­o como suÃ©teres, chamarras, cobertores, etc. para la temporada de invierno que se acerca.
texts.en:
Aurelia is married. Her husband is a heavy machinery mechanic at a factory that manufactures sea platforms. They have 3 teenage children. She started her business because she wanted some extra money, as even though she works as a nurse, family income was not enough to pay for the home expenses and her daughterâ€™s school. She began selling cosmetics at work and her neighbors' but as the business started to grow she decided to sell plastic home items, as they are very popular among house wives. Little by little her business has been making progress. Six months ago, she decided to start selling clothes as she realized this could also be a great deal of business. Her clothes sales have had amazing acceptance among her customers. She needs a $375 loan that will be repaid bi-weekly, over 5 months to purchase merchandise to fulfill her plastic items requests and to purchase winter clothes, such as sweaters, ponchos, coats, and others.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase plastic home products

loan.name: Saturnina

Saturnina makes a living selling different kinds of merchandise. Saturnina lives in rental housing in the Irpavi neighborhood of La Paz. She has two school-aged children. This is her fourth Impro loan. Her history qualifies her as a premier customer because she has successfully repaid past loans.

loan.name: Navoneiwa

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and SELFINA! This is 32 year old Navoneiwa R J.. She is married with three children between the ages of 5 and 19 and she is proud to report that all of them are in school.
In April 2008, she started a shoe selling business and has been running it since with the assistance of her husband. Her business has been doing well and her monthly profits are about USD100. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional shoes, sandals and slippers. Due to the success of this business, she hopes to be able to open another business in the future. She thanks you in advance for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.name: Upendo

Mambo (Greetings!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and SELFINA! This is 31 year old Upendo J K.. She is a married mother of two children who are 6 and 8 years old.
She runs a grocery store and is assisted by her husband. She works at her business 10 hours a day and 6 days per week. Her business is doing well and her monthly profits are approximately US$250. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, wheat flour, sugar, maize flour, and some animal feed. Due to the success of her business, she hopes to open another business in the future. She thanks you in advance for your support.

The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

With the first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased wool to make knitwear to sell in her handicraft stand. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost a year.

With this 500.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase wool and handicrafts to sell in her stand.

Francisca continues to work in order to support her family.

He used to have a similar job until her was fired, so he decided to start its own business with the help of his wife. He opened his business in August 1996 using all the knowledge he acquired in his old job. He bought all the necessary supplies, such as screens and reflectors for silk-screen print developing and he opened a shop at home where he currently works. After years of experience and using his sales person skills acquired in a previous job, it wasnâ€™t hard for him to start his own clientele always guaranteeing the best prices. With her first loan for S/ 300 she bought candy to sell in her store. She has been working with the Communal Bank for almost 5 years and she tells us that she is trained as a nurse technician but does not practice this profession. With this loan for S/. 1,000, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy toys and fireworks for the Christmas season. Hilda wishes to continue working to build her own home.

loan.name: Nsia

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and SELFINA! This is 33 year old Nsia I. M.. She is married with three children between the ages of 2 and 8.
Nsia is quite the entrepreneur as she runs two businesses: a kuku (poultry) business and a tailoring business. Seems a bit unrelated to the average person, but it makes sense here in Tanzania. A kuku business is a simple, profitable, and popular business here in Tanzania. You simply buy chicks, tend to them for 5 weeks, and then sell them in the market. It does not take all day to tend to the chickens, once in the morning and once in the afternoon, so a go-getter like Nsia also has time to run another business. Her tailoring business is a bit more complicated as she needs to properly measure and sew outfits to her customers' specifications, and customers can be quite demanding!
Her businesses are doing well and her monthly profits are approximately US$600. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional chicks and feed for her kuku business, as well as materials for making clothes for her tailoring business. She thanks you in advance for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase additional chicks and feed for her kuku business, as well as materials for her tailoring business.

loan.name: Lucy

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Lucy es socia del Banco Comunal â€œDante Navaâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 30 aÃ±os de edad, es casada y madre de un hijo. Con su primer prÃ©stamo de S/. 300 comprÃ³ cosmÃ©ticos, bisuterÃ­a para venderlos en su puesto de trabajo. Tiene casi 8 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que su quisco ha variado de productos, tiene pelotas, juguetes y regalos para toda ocasiÃ³n. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 3,000, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprarÃ¡ peluches, cofres de hueso y tintes para cabello para vender en la campaÃ±a navideÃ±a.

SeÃ±ora Lucy is a member of the communal bank "Dante Nava" in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 30, is married, and has one son. With her first loan of 300 nuevos soles, she purchased cosmetics and jewelry to sell at her stand where she works. She has worked for almost 8 years with the communal bank, and she tells us that she sells various products at her kiosk. She has balls, toys, and gifts for every occasion. With this loan of 3,000 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase stuffed animals, jewelry boxes, and hair dyes to sell during the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Antonio iniciÃ³ el negocio ya que necesitaba de una actividad econÃ³mica para solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar a sus padres econÃ³micamente ya que son personas adultas mayores. ComenzÃ³ el negocio en Junio del 2000 trabajaba junto con la muchacha que es su ayudante en una fabrica y una vez que fueron despedidos decidieron asociarse e iniciar un negocio de elaboraciÃ³n y venta de donas y empanadas. Al inicio tuvieron que tocar muchas puertas para dar a conocer su producto y poder vender, pero una vez que los fueron conociendo se ha dedicado a surtir los pedidos que diariamente les solicitan.
El necesita un prÃ©stamo por MXN $6,000 que pagara en 6 meses para poder comprar materia prima y con esto bajar el costo y consecuentemente tener mayor utilidad para continuar reinvirtiendo en el negocio.
texts.en:
Antonio started this business because he needed an activity to cover his personal expenses and to financially support his parents as they are both elder people. He opened his business in June 2000 after him and his partner, a woman that used to work with him at a factory, were fired. After that, they decided to become partners and get into the business of making doughnuts and â€œempanadasâ€. At the beginning they had to knock on many doors to be able to sell their products, but once customers started to know them they have expanded their business and they are now devoted to prepare and deliver the many requests they receive every day. He needs a loan of $450 that will be canceled in 6 months to purchase raw material that will allow them to lower the cost of their products to have a better utility and to continue re-investing in this business.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase raw material

loan.name: Lucila Yobana

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Lucila es socia del Banco Comunal â€œWiÃ±ayâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 40 aÃ±os de edad y es soltera sin hijos. Tiene casi 3 aÃ±os trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que ha trabajado en el sector transportes y se comprÃ³ una computadora nueva para la inscripciÃ³n de vehÃ­culos. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,700, el cual serÃ¡ cancelado en 4 cuotas, pretende independizarse y comprar lubricantes y un scanner para su taller de mecÃ¡nica.

SeÃ±ora Lucila is a member of the communal bank, "WiÃ±ay," in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 40 and is single with no children. With her first loan of 300 nuevos soles, she bought parts to sell in her mechanic's shop. She has worked with the communal bank for almost 3 years, and she tells us that she has worked in the transportation sector and has bought a new computer for vehicle registration. With this loan of 1,700 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she hopes to become independent and to purchase lubricants and a scanner for her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Rosario Isabel

texts.es: Rosario iniciÃ³ el negocio en Marzo de 2004, porquÃ© deseaba obtener un ingreso propio para no tener que depender totalmente de su esposo en el aspecto econÃ³mico y ademÃ¡s querÃ­a contribuir ayudando con los estudios de sus hijos. EmpezÃ³ gracias a una persona que le ofreciÃ³ productos naturistas para uso persona, pero al notar los resultados que le dieron empecÃ© a ofrecerlos entre familiares y amigos Ella siente que ha ido progresando porque desde hace un aÃ±o tambiÃ©n se dedico a vender joyerÃ­a de plata la cual tambiÃ©n logro vender entres sus clientes de los productos naturistas y gracias a su negocio puede costear la carrera universitaria de su hija. Ahora necesita de un prÃ©stamo por MXN $5,000 que pagara en 10 catorcenas para comprar mercancÃ­a que le permitirÃ¡ comprar mas productos para poder cubrir pedidos de sus clientes y tambiÃ©n para comprar joyerÃ­a de plata aprovechando esta temporada navideÃ±a que se acerca y en la que la gente compra mÃ¡s para hacer regalos
texts.en:
Rosario started the business in March of 2004. She wanted to have her own income and not totally depend on her husband economically. She also wanted to help pay for her children's education. She started thanks to a person who offered her natural products for personal use. When she noticed the results, she began offering them to family and friends.

She feels her business has improved because she began selling silver jewelry a year ago. She was able to sell the jewelry to her customers who buy the natural products. Thanks to her business she can pay for her daughter's university education.

Now she needs a loan for MXN $5,000 to buy merchandise which she will pay back in 10 bi-monthly installments. This will allow her to buy more products to cover her customers' orders and also buy silver jewelry, taking advantage of the upcoming Christmas season when people buy more to give as presents.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: purchase merchandise

loan.name: Maritza Yovana

texts.es: La seÃ±ora Maritza es socia del Banco Comunal â€œMujeres de Villa del Lago IIâ€ del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 30 aÃ±os de edad, es conviviente y madre de 2 hijos menores a los que apoya econÃ³micamente. Con el primer prÃ©stamo de S/ 500 comprÃ³ gaseosas para vender al por mayor. Tiene casi un aÃ±o trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que ha aumentado la cantidad de productos que compra al contado de las distribuidoras. Maritza desea continuar trabajando para apoyar a sus hijos para que lleguen a ser profesionales.

She has worked with the communal bank for almost a year, and she tells us that she has increased the amount of products that she buys from distributors with cash. With this first loan of 1,300 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy a larger quantity of soft drinks to keep distributing as a wholesaler. Maritza hopes to keep working to support her children so they will become professionals.
